title: Erdős Problem #1051: Irrationality of Reciprocal Product Series
description: If a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ are integers with lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1, is Σ 1/(aₙ·aₙ₊₁) irrational? Known for rapid growth aₙ₊₁ ≥ C·aₙ². OPEN in general.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham (1980, p.64) posed this problem about irrationality of series formed from rapidly growing integer sequences. Erdős (1988) proved the result for sequences satisfying aₙ₊₁ ≥ C·aₙ² (quadratic growth), but the general case with only lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1 remains open.
overview.problemStatement: If a₁ < a₂ < ⋯ is a strictly increasing integer sequence with lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1, is Σ 1/(aₙ · aₙ₊₁) irrational?
overview.proofStrategy: We define GrowthCondition (lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1) and erdosSeries (Σ 1/(aₙ·aₙ₊₁)). ErdosProblem1051 states universal irrationality. The solved rapid growth case is axiomatized. Convergence and positivity are stated, along with the related simple reciprocal series question.
keyInsights: lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1 implies doubly exponential growth
Erdős (1988) proved irrationality when aₙ₊₁ ≥ C·aₙ² (rapid growth)
The gap between the growth condition and the proved case is the open problem
Related: Σ 1/aₙ may also be irrational under the same growth condition

sections.title: Growth Condition
sections.summary: Defines GrowthCondition: lim inf aₙ^{1/2ⁿ} > 1 via Filter.liminf.

sections.title: The Series
sections.summary: Defines erdosSeries: Σ 1/(aₙ · aₙ₊₁) using tsum.

sections.title: The Conjecture
sections.summary: States ErdosProblem1051: the series is always irrational under the growth condition.

sections.title: Rapid Growth Case (Solved)
sections.summary: Erdős (1988): irrationality holds when aₙ₊₁ ≥ C·aₙ² for some C > 0.

sections.title: Convergence
sections.summary: The series converges absolutely under the growth condition and is positive when aₙ > 0.

sections.title: Related Series
sections.summary: The simpler Σ 1/aₙ question and the Sylvester–Fibonacci example.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 1051 asks whether Σ 1/(aₙ·aₙ₊₁) is always irrational for doubly-exponentially growing integer sequences. The rapid growth case (aₙ₊₁ ≥ C·aₙ²) is solved. The general case is open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would advance the theory of irrationality of series with integer terms, connecting growth rates to number-theoretic properties of infinite sums.
openQuestions: Is Σ 1/(aₙ·aₙ₊₁) irrational under the full growth condition?
Is Σ 1/aₙ also irrational under the same growth condition?
What is the weakest growth condition ensuring irrationality?
